noun.description: A paid position of regular employment.
examples: jobs are created in the private sector, not in Washington

noun.description: A task or piece of work, especially one that is paid.
examples: she wants to be left alone to get on with the job
you did a good job of explaining

noun.description: A thing of a specified kind.
examples: the car was a blue malevolent-looking job

verb.description: Buy and sell (stocks) as a broker-dealer, especially on a small scale.
Turn a public office or a position of trust to private advantage.

proper noun.description: (in the Bible) a prosperous man whose patience and piety were tried by undeserved misfortunes, and who, in spite of his bitter lamentations, remained confident in the goodness and justice of God.

phrases: a piece of board will do the job
The ever-diminishing crew suddenly discover that the nukes on board just will not do the job.
Not that women can't do the job, just that they tend to do other vital jobs better.
Not only does he have the ability to do the job, he also has the integrity to do the job.
It did the job, but requires an extra hole being cut in your boat, plus cumbersome additional steps during fueling.
all the work done by the middleman can be jobbed out at a much lower cost
origin: Late Middle English: apparently symbolic of a brief forceful action (compare with jab).
